title: Boy, 10, who fled to Britain when father was murdered by Taliban in Afghanistan 'told to leave UK'
text:
News Boy, 10, who fled to Britain when father was murdered by Taliban in Afghanistan 'told to leave UK' Bashir Naderi, who is now 19, has spent almost half of his life living in Wales but is now set to leave the country Share Bashir Naderi is back in Cardiff after a campaign to stop his deportation (Photo: South Wales Echo) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
A teenager born in Afghanistan has been refused permission to remain in the UK despite spending half his life in Wales. 
Bashir Naderi, 19, fled to Britain from Afghanistan when he was 10 years old after his father was murdered by the Taliban. 
A petition signed by more than 14,000 people was handed to the Home Office earlier this month after he was ordered for forced removal by the Home Office in November last year. 
This was put on hold after a stay of removal was obtained just a few hours before he was due to board a flight to Kabul, reports Wales Online . Read More 
But a decision has reportedly been made by the Home Office to refuse Bashir, who lives in Cardiff, leave to remain in the UK. He was almost removed to Afghanistan but there was a brief last-minute reprieve (Photo: Rex Features) 
Writing on Facebook, Bashir’s partner Nicole Cooper said: “Sorry guys, I was hoping the next status about Bash’s situation would be wonderful news. Unfortunately that isn’t the case. 
“Bash has been refused leave by the Home Office. His legal team ‘Cardiff Office of Duncan Lewis Solicitors’ are going to challenge his position. 
“Bash, myself and our families are heartbroken by this decision but we can’t give up! Please keep up your support, we need it now more than ever!” 
Bashir, who lives in Cathays and attended Mary Immaculate High School before going on to study painting and decorating at Cardiff and Vale College, has had no contact with his mother since he left Afghanistan in 2007. Bashir with his girlfriend Nicole Cooper outside the Home Office in London (Photo: PA) The pair with Cardiff Central MP Jo Stevens (Photo: Rex Features) 
It took him a year to reach the UK and he was eventually placed with a foster family in Cardiff. 
Speaking at the time about living with his foster mum Dawn Jackson, Bashir said: “I couldn’t have been happier. After my schooling had finished and I had an amazing prom to end the year. Read More 
“I went straight into full-time education in college to learn more in English and maths, completed and passed [and] I then went on to complete a six-month course doing construction. 
“I am now studying painting and decorating level two and sitting exams.” 
The Home Office have been asked to comment. Like us on Facebook
